issue.title: [C++] Only enable jemalloc background_thread if feature is supported
issue.body:
***Note**: This issue was originally created as [ARROW-6977](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977). Please see the [migration documentation](https://gist.github.com/toddfarmer/12aa88361532d21902818a6044fda4c3) for further details.*

### Original Issue Description:
Followup to ARROW-6910. When loading the R package after that patch merged, I get this new message:

```Java

$ R
> library(arrow)
<jemalloc>: option background_thread currently supports pthread only

```

https://github.com/jemalloc/jemalloc/blob/3d84bd57f4954a17059bd31330ec87d3c1876411/src/background_thread.c#L884-L887 is where the message comes from. Tracing that further, `have_background_thread` comes from https://github.com/jemalloc/jemalloc/blob/21cfe59ff7b10a61dabe26cd3dbfb7a255e1f5e8/include/jemalloc/internal/jemalloc_preamble.h.in#L205-L211, which gets set in `configure.ac` here: https://github.com/jemalloc/jemalloc/blob/d2dddfb82aac9f2212922eb90324e84790704bfe/configure.ac#L2155-L2157

In sum, on my system, that flag doesn't get set, so `have_background_thread` is false, and when that is false and the `background_thread` option is true, I get that message printed. And I do not want to see that message.

cc `[~wesm]`

comments.body:
***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958205) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
This sounds critical to get in for 0.15.1, right?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958212) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
I'm not sure, but it sounds like the kind of thing we'll hear bug reports about if we don't. 

For the CRAN R packages, it's not an issue because the macOS and Windows binaries are built with jemalloc disabled:

- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/59a6788c76330cf055bdbcbc7bdae7b0106c6656/dev/tasks/homebrew-formulae/autobrew/apache-arrow.rb#L47
- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/59a6788c76330cf055bdbcbc7bdae7b0106c6656/ci/PKGBUILD#L85

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958214) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
I wonder why this didn't come up on CI. Is macOS younger on Travis? `[~kszucs]`

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958215) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
It's just a message, it doesn't appear to error, at least not immediately.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958216) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
Ah... can you run the tests fine? Also the C++ tests.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958219) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
That said, I am experiencing this error occasionally today while running the R test suite locally. This is on master:

```Java

...
CsvTableReader: ......Assertion failed: (ec == 0), function unlock, file /BuildRoot/Library/Caches/com.apple.xbs/Sources/libcxx/libcxx-400.9.4/src/mutex.cpp, line 48.
/bin/sh: line 1: 59468 Abort trap: 6           R --slave -e 'library(testthat); setwd(file.path(.libPaths()[1], "arrow", "tests")); system.time(test_check("arrow", filter="", reporter=ifelse(nchar(""), "", "summary")))'
make: *** [test] Error 134
```

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958253) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
Not having pthread seems a bit weird to me, I'm not sure what that is all about?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958287) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
The error message is misleading, it's about missing another system call. Unless we can find a reliable version check, disabling the background thread on macOS may be the safest course of action. `[~uwe]`

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958288) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
`[~npr]` can you produce a gdb backtrace for that error?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958290) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
With some handholding, I'm sure I could.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958294) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
Update: I wiped my build dir and rebuilt with `-DARROW_JEMALLOC=OFF`. I no longer get the warning message, but I'm still able to trigger this abort. So it seems there's something new in master that triggers this, but it may not be jemalloc background thread.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958295) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
You can try running the executable using "gdb --args".

Another solution is to enable core dumps (perhaps "ulimit -c unlimited") and then run gdb on the core dump, like this: "gdb executable_file core_file".

Once under the gdb, use "run" to run the application and then "bt" to get a backtrace.  If debugging a core dump, you only need "bt".

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958302) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
Could you post the backtrace for all threads? Something like "thread apply all bt" should do.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958304) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
Also, it would be nice if you could give a bit of context? (why is the test doing? can you run them in verbose mode to see where it's crashing?)

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958305) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
It most often fails in the CSV reader, which itself has multithreading (recently revised?) and when the data is pulled from Arrow into and R data.frame, it also uses threads.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958313) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
Yeah, but what does the test it fails in precisely do?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958316) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
It doesn't always fail in the same place. Sometimes I see three test assertions pass and then it fails, which means that it errors before the next assertion. Which would put it somewhere around https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-csv.R#L43-L45. But other times it doesn't fail on that block and fails later. 

I'll try rewriting the tests to disambiguate and see if there's a pattern of where exactly it fails.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958318) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
On this particular crash (after 14 assertions passed), it looks like https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-csv.R#L119 was the line that crashed. But like I said, it sometimes doesn't fail there, sometimes fails earlier, and sometimes fails in a different test file.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958327) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
Re-running a bunch now, I've crashed here (to the best of my estimation):

- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-csv.R#L43
- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-csv.R#L44
- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-csv.R#L45 (3x)
- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-csv.R#L58-L59
- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-Table.R#L133-L135
- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-Table.R#L140
- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-Table.R#L189-L192
- https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/tests/testthat/test-Table.R#L196-L205

  About 2 out of 3 times the test suite completes cleanly.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958435) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
The thread pool thing seems to be a new issue, can we open a JIRA for that?

What do you want to do about the background thread issue? We can set decay_ms=0 by default with no background thread, but I'm not sure what the performance impact will be.

Creating packages without jemalloc is not a good idea because of the performance implications.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-6977?focusedCommentId=16958490) by Neal Richardson (npr):*
I made ARROW-6983 for the threading issue. ARROW-6979 is for the jemalloc for macOS R packages; do I remember correctly that jemalloc isn't available for Windows?

As for this issue, assuming it's innocuous, it's just annoying that every time I load the package I get this message. I don't know how to suppress it though. It would be nice if we could set background_thread: true in our code based on the same condition that jemalloc is checking.
